Don't want to hurt anybody's feelings, but I see many Americans ordering lasagna or pasta carbonara on the Amalfi Coast.We Italians have hundreds of typical disces that are best eaten from where they are originally (because we know they use the best, fresh ingredients they bought at the local market)
So, once and for all: lasagna is from Emilia Romagna, where Bologna is.
Pasta carbonara, cacio e pepe, from Rome .
While in Amalfi try instead the rich local cuisine : mozzarella, tomatoes, seafood pasta, seafood dishes, pasta alla Nerano (zucchini and a very specific cheese called provolone del monaco).
You know how sensitive we are about food;), but please do just a little research♡

text: Do you need an international driving permit to rent a car in Italy?

comments.comment_text: Last time I went I did not have one. Rental company kinda blustered about it a bit but then rented me the car anyway.
Cindy Rittenberry
Better to be safe than sorry. It’s only 20 dollars on AAA
Yes! Rental car company asked for it first thing.
AAA check it out
Yes! When we picked up our rental we saw a couple get turned away from their reservation because they didn't have one. Also it's super easy, quick and cheap to get one.

The answer is no and yes.
While it’s possible to rent the car you wouldn’t have any insurance.

The rental company doesn’t care because your liable for damage no matter what.
AAA can hook you up for about $20.
Yes! Go to AAA
Not this again!

An IDP is a certified translation of your actual license.
Local governments can be fussy if your license is not in a language used locally.
Best to carry one in case you are stopped by a cranky policeman!
Better to get one. Why take the chance, not expensive.
O my god…
If you don't get an international DL the car rental company will charge you more money for insurance, that happened to my son.
No
A permit is the least of your problem, it’s knowing how to drive like a local and constantly pushing the horn.
The rental company will want to see one
I got one from AAA for about $40 bucks, but it was never checked by anyone. Not even the car rental place.
Only if you are not from the EU/EFTA
If you're not sure, just go ahead and get one. Took me about 5 minutes at AAA
Yes
Not sure , but I got one anyway. I got it through AAA for less then $30 good for a year.
We were asked for it from rental company
Yes. But if you don't have it it is not a problem.
Our travel agent told us we need to. It’s only $30
No but you need one to DRIVE THAT RENTAL.
Sandy Radican Shikaly
Sandy Radican Shikaly
Yes
Where are you coming from?
AAA with a photo and like $50 for a year
My question is...how easy is it to drive in italy. Are there lots of crazy drivers. No disrespect intended
I had to show mine when I rented our car.
No we are here and No
Yes
$20 plus $6 for the two required photos at AAA, valid for 1 year from the date you identify your trip starts. I got mine from AAA in May but good for 1 year from Sep 1 2023.
Around 50 bucks do it on line and get it emailed to yourself
you do i am required to for my rental car .. its in my booking .. but some don't bother.. for the few dollars they cost I don't see why people don't..
For the little price it will cost you, you should have one in case.
Si certo
No. 7 trips over and renting every time never had one.
No
No
I wasn't ask for an international license when I rented a car in italy
Google! You will see you need one.
Yes, rented cars twice in Italy had to show international permit both times.
Yes,got done for illegal parking it was the first thing the police asked for
Not really, you just need an European passport and any driving license
Yes $20at AAA

Do you need a license to drive in the US? Only if you get caught...

Same with this, you need it when you need it - you had better have it when you need it...

It's fast, cheap and easy. Why not get it?
We rented a car with hertz and all they asked for was US drivers license. No issues!

Triple A will provide the license you need, we took 23 people to Italy January 2019, every couple had a car rental but all most every couple got a $400.00 ticket sent to them a month after they arrived back from vacation.. the ticket was for driving in a neighborhood that didn’t allow traffic.. you will regret driving is my opinion.. sounds wonderful but it was a nightmare, we drove from Milan To Florence…. Once in Florence our group took the train to Rome, Venice and other stops instead of driving. the train system is so good you can go anywhere you want by train.. we are returning to Rome and Naples January 2024 but will never drive in Italy again.

Yes. $20 with AAA and it’s good for a year. Better be safe then sorry

If you have an accident over there your insurance covers with an international license

I’d like to see the Tuscany region and Amalfi Coast or Sicily (undecided as to which yet). Just wondering if anyone has any recommendations as to where to stay in Rome, Tuscany and/or things to do? Also, any advise as to which would be better Amalfi or Sicily? Thinking of only staying in Rome for 1 night.
Hi everyone. I’m from Canada. When travelling to Italy is it best to purchase a SIM card there rather than adding a travel package to your phone before leaving? If so, where can you purchase?

comments.comment_text: Canadian here. Buy an esim card at the airport when you arrive. We use Vodafone. Usually around 15€ for 35 gig. You can Hotspot other phones to it. I suggest taking an old cell with no apps installed. Battery will last all day. If you need to contact anyone at home use What's app

text: Best way to book tickets to Milan Duomo including rooftop please.

Our Travel agent is saying if we want to see Florence we need to fly there then Rome and then Sorrento and fly out of Naples? Is this right? We ditched Sicily but trying to figure out what are the must sees in Florence and is Venice a must see? This will
Most likely be my only trip to Italy but not keen on hotel hoping every few days. Or do I just need to get over it? My son wants to see the ruins, I want a vineyard and the beach 😀

comments.comment_text: It depends on where you are coming from. I think you need to connect from somewhere else in Europe to fly to Florence. Rome Milan Venice more accessible for direct flights
Venice got a beach Florence not

All these places your asking if they are a “must see”, please read a little about them so you know the answer. So much to just easily google. These places are like no other on earth, they are one of a kind. Your travel agent is trying to get you from one direction to the next without back tracking, but fly in and out of where ever you like.
Go on a cruise
How many days are you in Italy?
Might skip Sorrento- flying into Rome train to Florence fly out of Venice. If Sorrento is a must a little backtracking is involved.

We flew into Naples and spent 3 nights in Sorrento, then took the train to Florence for 2 nights, then took the train to Rome for 3 nights and flew home from Rome. It did mean we went a little out of our way in the middle. I can't really remember why our travel agent decided to set it up that way, but I did like the idea of flying out of Rome because I felt it had more flights out if one got cancelled or delayed. We wanted to fly direct to Italy from NY/NJ so she was also working with that.

You don’t “need” to do that, with that said you won’t back track in your schedule doing it that way.

Florence is more $$$ to fly into and most flights will have a connection in Rome anyway.

I’d it this way:
*Fly into Rome stay a few days there.
*Train to Florence stay a few days there.
*Train to Sorrento (or Naples then ferry or car to Sorrento) stay a few days. Pompeii is an easy day trip from Sorrento on the local train.
*last night in Naples then fly home from there.

Of course you can easily do this as a RT from Rome. We did almost this same itinerary with RT Rome. We stayed in San Gimignano and saw more of Tuscany with a day trip to Florence.

RT flight from Rome will most likely be your cheapest option.

Your travel agent is telling you that because it makes the most sense geographically.


We found that the flight was direct, and cheaper if we fly to Rome.

High speed trains are fast in Italy.
Rome to Florence in 1:33. €34
Florence to Naples in 3:13 €52

Venice is worth seeing, but unless you want to hotel hop, you may not have time for it

Just a consideration - but into Florence and out of Naples might be logistically optimal but flying out of Rome might be half the cost is you don't mind backtracking a little. That said, you will want to hotel hop. Pick your entry and exit cities and take trains from city to city figuring for about 3'ish hours for travel between each.

We are flying into Milan, immediately training up to Como for 3 nights then back down to Florence for 3 nights, then to Sorrento for 5 nights then up to Rome for 2 nights then back to the USA. We have multiple day trips and tours at each place.
We fly into Rome, train to Florence, train to naples, stay in Sorrento, fly out Naples, over 10 days
We are flying into Rome, then train to Florence, then train to Sorento. And flying home out of Naples
We fly into Naples, visit Amalfi Coast and then head to my Grandparents villages then onto Florence and Rome and depart back to US from Rome
Fast train from Florence to Venice. Yes it is worth seeing. Easy to get there and back. Easy ride to Tuscany from Florence also… we hired a driver. Pretty ride.
I loved basing out of Sorrento had a beach day a boat day and a trip to the Amalfi Coast and ruins day.

Have not checked flight prices but may be that flight to Florence is less than to Rome (I believe smaller airport). I believe many cruise lines have persons fly into/out of Rome and then transfer to the port at Civitavecchia. From Florence it is an easy train ride to Rome. From Rome can also get a train to Sorrento. From Sorrento it is a shorter distance to Naples than to return to Rome. Again, a flight out of Naples may be less costly and easier than from Rome.
We did Rome, Florence then Sorrento and flew out of Naples home

The Florence airport is a smaller one. I think you’d find many more options for direct flights to either Milan or Rome so I’d consider those options as well. Of course that depends on where you’re flying from and what season you’re flying. ( I strongly prefer to fly direct rather than be faced with connections so Florence would probably not be my choice for that reason alone. Once time I did fly to NYC from Florence but had to connect in Milan.)

Keep in mind that there are usually several different ways to travel. Which is why I prefer to plan independently instead of using a travel agent. I know what’s best for myself. Maybe the travel agent doesn’t want to take the time to research each possibility. But another option would be to fly round trip to Rome and make a circuit of the cities you plan to visit. Or to fly into Milan then go in order to Florence, Rome snd Sorrento flying back from Naples or going back to Rome to fly out. There are several possibilities. i’d research all the options and decide which best suit my needs. Remember that you can usually plan your ground itinerary around almost any international flight arrangements.

And as far as “must sees” anywhere only you can know what is a must see for you. It really depends on your personal interests and preferences. You might want to read a few travel guides to get a feel about what attractions appeal to you.
That's why I don't go through a travel agent. It seems like they plan it how they think would be best for you. Do it your way and how you wanna do it... ditch the travel agent.
I am giving up o. Florence as we just don’t have enough time . Flying to Rome, the. Naples, the. Amalfi coast
How long will you be there? I think if it's your only trip, Venice should be on it.
We flew into Venice, then to Florence, Rome, and Sorrento…flew out of Naples.
Rome - Florence - Venice. Ruins in Rome, vineyards near Florence & beaches near Venice. Plus all sorts of great other stuff in those 3 places.
No! Take the train. Cheaper to fly into Rome

Don’t discount returning to Italy - I went for a month and still feel as though I missed so much. Trains are pretty easy if you travel with light luggage (I was alone and managed ok). Easiest to fly into Rome - you can take trains to Venice, Florence, Milano, Naples all only a few hours. My best advice is work out what you really want to see - do research -and work around that. And then plan to go back some day and do the rest 😊

How long have you got in Italy ?
You can get a high speed train from Rome to Florence in about 2 hrs
If you’re able to, you can easily take the trains. It is absurd to think that you have to fly to every city. Ditch this travel agent, horrible advice.
No. Fly to Rome or Milan. Whatever is cheaper. And then take the trains.
We flew into Rome, stayed a week and then took the train to Florence

Use the trains save money and they are fast... train Florence to Rome, we have taken the train between Rome and naples twice so glad we did. ...bonus beautiful country side. In naples schedule a day tour to Sorrento and if you have time go to Pompei not far from Naples or take a ferry to Capri if you will be in naples a few days. Have fun!

How much time do you have? We are flying in to Venice, 3 nights, then on to Florence, for 2, Tuscany 4, sorrento 3, Positano 2 and back to Rome for 4 then fly home from there. 3 weeks.

If less than that and those are the places you want to see yes that makes sense.
When I was looking for flights it was cheaper to fly into Rome than the other cities.
I’m flying in / out of Rome but starting in Florence 🙂
We are flying into Rome, going to Florence and flying out of Venice.
We started in Rome, 4 days, Sorrento, 3 days with day trip to Capri, Florence, 4 days, and then Venice for two days. Was perfect!
Fly into Rome, Trains are great and high speed. Don't skip Lake Como!

I think your agent is saying that to avoid you backtracking. However, the train between Rome and Florence is easy and fast. From the US, the air RT from Rome is significantly cheaper anytime I check than flying in one city and out another. For me, Rome was always much cheaper than RT any other major city. 🤷‍♀️ The logistics of Rome to Naples/
Sorrento and back is more time consuming. So I’d check prices of flying into Naples and out of Rome - not worrying about the short train ride to do Florence. If your interest is ruins and beach, then maybe Venice isn’t a “must”.🤷‍♀️

In Naples book a day with https://
www.facebook.com
/taxitournapoli. He will take you to Pompeii and Herculaneum, Pompeii - but after that he will take you to a winery! We did this earlier in the month and it was fantastic. He even arranged a guide for Pompeii and Herculaneum - which is really recommended!! Enjoy.
How long is your trip?
We are planning at keast 3 wks next spring, Sicily is in our plans.You can fly fr Florence to Sicily ,inexpensive .

I would see Rome for sure.
I would stay outside Florence & see Florence & try to see a few towns in Tuscany - maybe stay in one. Don’t remember distances (& will you have a car) but towns we visited & just loved - Lucca, Siena, Volterre, San giamignano.
Sorrento is gorgeous & you could also see Capri from there &/or positano/
Amalfi (but do those by boat or personal driver out of Sorrento). You could do highlights of Florence in a day if u want more time in small towns. Tuscany is my favorite!
Venice is kind of a must see although it’s not my favorite. That said I love Murano & burano via water taxi out of Venice. So just not sure how ur time is but I would stay in one place at least 3 days & maybe do some day trips.
Tuscany requires a car. So that may also determine what u can do

We had planned Boston to Sicily (stuck in Paris due to strike) so flew from Paris to Venice, train from Venice to Florence, train from Florence to Rome, train from Rome to Naples (Sorrento/
Positano area), train from Naples to Rome and Flying home from Rome to Boston. Definitely a lot of moving around but we planned to start vacation with a beach and end vacation with a beach and all of the sites in between!!
We’re flying into Rome and out of Rome but traveling by train to our destinations.

We flew into Rome and spent 3 days there ..Hotel Concordia..cent
rally located. We took a beautiful train down to Naples..nice scenery it was and J&J Transfer again to Maiori...across
from Tyranian Sea beach/ boardwalk. We stayed at Hotel Panorama,( very pleased) and there are others there as well.Both hotels were rooftop breakfasts included. Flew out of Naples to Newark, NJ.

We are flying into Rome and out of Venice
3 nights Rome
4 nights Tuscany (opted for some relaxation rather then Florence we will go for a day)
3 nights near Genoa ( family from there so want to see where grandparents were from)
3 nights Venice
We have a car when we leave Rome until we get to Venice.
We flew into Rome and did day trips to Florence and Sorrento by train.

Venice is such a unique place, and with rising seas, its days may be numbered. That said, only you can decide what interests you. Italy draws you back and we have our third trip coming up, and we'll make it to Venice this time. Our first trip was a tour of Sicily and it was incredible. We flew into Rome, spent a few days there (a MUST on my bucket list), then flew to Palermo to start the tour.

Try not to stress too much, wherever you go will be wonderful, and you'll likely go back to see more. Just try not to go during the hottest months if you avoid it.

Hi all,

We had difficulty calling a taxi when we stayed in the Florence hills last October. I know of no taxi app for Florence where you can order one. (Maybe one exists but we did not find it). As to calling one —I understand Italian and can speak some. BUT just getting beyond the automated message to actually speak to someone was impossible because it was spoken so fast. I could not understand it to move to the next step. That’s just my experience— maybe others have been more successful. But I don’t see how you will call for one if you aren’t very very good in the language.
My daughter lives outside of Florence but there is a good bus service.
Bus & train services are good but taxi in countryside not reliable.
Check out the itTaxi app. I use it in Florence but I’m not sure if it works outside of Florence.
Unless you want to pay $$ for private transfers you are best to book a place on the train line or with bus service to Florence. Otherwise maybe rent a car.

It will be difficult unless the airbnb has a bus stop nearby.
Relying on taxis or private drivers to go back and forth will be expensive and frustrating.
In any case you won’t be able to have a stroll in Florence in the evening and you’ll be very limited in your restaurant choice.
Also it is very nice (and easy) to drive around in the countryside, full of little villages and beautiful spots, and staying there without a car you’ll miss most of it.

During a recent visit I found there were plenty of taxis at the main train station but getting a taxi elsewhere was a nightmare even if I tried to order one hours prior. No Uber there either. It's a personal choice if you want to stay out of town but in my opinion being in the city centre was amazing. I'd talk to your Airbnb host. I've found bus services in Tuscany are usually pretty good. Enjoy your trip.

We tried to hire a taxi or uber from Impruneta, which is literally 15 minutes drive from the centre of Florence and we had no luck using the apps. Locals helped in the end by calling for us, but it took them nearly an hour to get through.

I stayed in Greve in Chianti for a week. Highly, and I mean highly, encourage you to either rent a car or stay closer to Florence. Tuscany countryside is beautiful but if you have interest in exploring it’s tough (and costly) to do that without renting a vehicle.

Not a stupid question at all. Outside of the cities taxis can be extremely difficult to get and expensive.
They will charge you twice...in that you pay for them from their starting point and the journey to your destination. So if they are coming from the town to pick you up you pay for that. Also beware of taxis/
cabs as we think of them and cars with drivers...which are much more expensive. I loved in Italy for many years and got caught out by this only last year our 'cab' turned out to be a (very casual)driver service

Good Morning from Florida, USA! I am leaving for Italy in a few days and I wanted some information on who to tip and approximate amounts. I always tip on the higher end in the US, but I keep hearing that tipping isn't a thing in Europe. I do not want to be disrespectful and not tip properly. My travel agent says that she always tips 20-25 percentआणखी of restaurants in Italy. But friends say gratuities are included and if you want to throw a few extra euros for great service, it's appreciated and you have to let them know ifs for the server. Can I get some opinions on how tipping is done? I'm also staying at some very nice hotels and I will be asking the concierge for some help. How much should I tip them and do I do it at the end, or after each time I ask for service? I apologize, I am not a seasoned overseas traveler. Going to visit my daughter who is studying abroad and then we are heading to Italy. Thank you!

comments.comment_text: At restaurant you leave 1/1.5 euro per person. That's enough.

Italian here: Not obligatory to tip, but we (Italians) always leave a few coins to round up the bill, e g. If your bill is 62 euros, you might round up to 65. If you get coffee and the barista is nice and quick, you might drop 10-20 cents in the tip jar. If there is no tip jar, leave those cents directly on the bar, next to the empty coffee cup (we don't sit to have coffee, we stand). People are likely to tell you: no tipping. It doesn't mean waiters won't appreciate it if you tip, they will obvioisly be grateful. If you read coperto on the menu, it refers to a sort of fixed cost to cover table cloth, napkins, cutlery (mostly in the city center; in Rome, in my neighbourhood - outside the center - they don't charge it. They might charge bread separately. Some touristy places charge "servizio". But tips are not included and you cannot tip using your credit card. If you did, the owner of the business would get that money (and pay taxes).
This might be helpful! Saw it posted from someone else in the group. Also, hello from a fellow Floridian 🌴
They will be happy with any amount you give them.They are paid a regular wage and don't rely on tips
We tipped everywhere and the same as we do in USA

Countries in Europe all have different practises, the countries aren't all the same. As a general rule of thumb tips are at your discretion and not normally added on unless a large table

The most common ways are 10% of total bill or rounding up the nearest 10

I always tip and I tip as if I was in the US unless service is awful … I have had servers tell me I’ve overpaid and they tried to give me back money ( that would rarely happen in the US)
They are so appreciative of what ever is given to them
We tipped the same as we do in Florida if the service was good and it was great in Positano

No tips ....
Period

You are not in the US. Respect other cultures and customs.
It’s not in European culture to tip the way you tip in US.
Tipping is not mandatory in Italy. In a full service restaurant we tipped 10%, and the wait staff was appreciative. Take out , no tip needed.

My husband and I returned from our Italy trip just two days ago, and it exceeded all of our expectations. An unexpected delight was a visit to a lovely little hilltop town called Orvieto, about 90 minutesआणखी north of Rome. As part of our bus tour, we knew nothing about it, but we found it to be charming and delightful in every possible way, it was definitely a highlight of our trip. We had only a couple of hours to explore, but we wish we could have spent the rest of the day! Orvieto is perched high up on a rock cliff, we rode a little cable car up a steep hill and there it was with 360 degree views of the countryside below. We loved strolling through the streets filled with flowers, vines and pretty shops, it looked like it came straight out of a storybook! Then we came across a stunning cathedral that took our breath away! It was covered with ornate, colorful carvings that shone in the sunlight. We did not want to leave this place! If you have a bit of extra time in your itinerary, I highly recommend a visit to Orvieto, you will not be disappointed!

text: Has anyone used a private boat service in Santa Margherita Ligure or Camogli? I would just like a short boat ride to take photos from the water and to take in the views. (nothing super expensive or fancy) 🚤

*edit* has anyone done #4?* Colosseum advice! This is the most important thing we want to see in our trip. Ticket sales allegedly open at 130am my time and I stayed up till 3am refreshing the window and never had a chance to get guided or unguided tix. They're instantly gone. I really don't want to book with a 3rd party, pay 2-3times as much and have them cancelled last minute. Those who've done it, how big of a deal was it to do the arena floor or the underground? So many questions.
1. What's in the 'arena'? Will we miss much if we don't go there?
2. Will it be that much better if we get a guided tour or would it be just as well listening to Rick Steves? Are there other audio tours out there as well for it?
3. Those with parco memberships, it says on the website they don't include the arena but I read somewhere that someone just showed their membership card and they were allowed on/in the arena.
4. Another membership question - thinking maybe the best thing for us to do is get the membership, book the underground night tour (extra cost) one night, then go the next day and do the rest of the colosseum. Any thoughts on this?

Thanks in advance, the information in this group has been so helpful!

comments.comment_text: Most overrated thing in Italy, in my opinion.

It is very hard to get the night tour. I wanted to do that but was not able to get tickets. I have done regular admission, underground, arena, as well as 3rd tier. All are good. If you can only get the regular admission, you will still see almost everything, just from farther away.
Get a tour guide!
Great question. I was wondering the same thing
Reggie

1. The arena is just the floor that overlooks the underground. You can get a similar view from other areas, so it’s not a must do but honestly get whatever tickets you can grab.

2. A guided tour helps you better understand what you are looking at. If you can’t get one, Rick Steves audio tour is a good alternative. You can also visit without any tour info.

3. ParCo has a link to book tickets that are just for entry. You have to grab the same tickets everyone else is vying for, just you don’t pay extra, since you have the membership. So while it is included, you still have to try and get tickets with the underground included.

4. ParCo was our backup plan if we couldn’t get regular tickets. I got regular tickets with an archaeologist, which unfortunately we were too late to hear the speech and ended up with just entrance. We also got night tour tickets to see the underground. Really awesome to see.
The Coliseum was the most underwhelming Part of our trips to rome. On subsequent trips we didn't even go there. The vatican complex is the jewel of all roman trips.

I'm not a fan of tours as much prefer to wander at my own pace. I buy tickets ahead of time from the official website ,(colosseo.it),
however you won't be able to enter the arena. It also can be a little confusing where to enter. If there's a big line outside, that's for people buying tickets. Should be a separate queue just to the right of it and you can basically walk right in after a security check.
Musement tours. Floor tour really explains the history. Also includes Skip the line.... And oh my the lines!!!

We considered the Colosseum as something we were going to do once on our first trip and likely not do again (unless we have grandkids at some point). The underground was pretty amazing/cool to see and in our opinion was a very important part of our visit to the Colosseum.

I have done the Colosseum 3 times - on 3 separate trips with different people and I have done a guided tour on each occasion and would not hesitate to do it again. To actually see how the gladiators and animals were in their ‘cells’ how the water was pumped in. The lifts that went up to the arena.
Each time it was different and the atmosphere under that arena floor is amazing and last year when I went with my teenager they had opened more underneath it was great.
The guides we had really know their stuff.
Loved it
Look on Viator and book a tour, many options

We just went and did a guided tour to the arena floor. We had been to Rome before and had regretted not going to the coloseum, it was probably one of the most disappointing things I've done in Rome. Our guide was nice, but we couldn't understand him. There are so many fascinating things to see in Rome I wouldn't spend too much time in the Coloseum. We were only there for a week and I had other things I would have liked to spend more time at in Rome. Glad I saw it, but don't need to do it again ever.

Last time I was in Rome you couldn't do anything in the colosseum because of stabilizing work being done. Yes it's been that long. I do want to get back there some day. Where I go its more than a day trip.

Private tour, we have done it twice and been to areas we would not have seen on our own or understood. A guide book can’t replace a real person, plus the time you save by skipping the long lines is worth it. This is usually a trip of a lifetime, so see as much as you can
We did a small guided tour and we were able to skip the long line. We did underground and above. We had tickets in advance.
Jackie Ahern
We did the underground tour a few weeks ago and loved it 😊

Not sure if you can do the underground without a tour - we got ours cancelled and had to rebook just the normal arena , so never got to go underground!
A lot of people I spoke to said the tour is amazing on a night with the underground ,

We hired a private guide. She was an archeologist who and done digs in the forum/. When you know what you are looking at and have an expert it comes alive. It was simply amazing. Our group of 4 adults were mesmerized. We are however lifelong learners and readers. A photo op would never have been enough.
Bobby Pequeno 🇮🇹

We did walks of Italy they do an excellent tour. Don’t miss the underground. It is one of the biggest parts of the Colosseum in my opinion. Seeing the area where the gladiators and animals were kept. You need to stand there and Really take it in. It was a brutal place in all reality. To see the charred walls where they had their fires to keep warm. People just Look at the exterior. You need to learn about what the guides will tell you about Blood and Bread day and what they did to feed their families.

We did the “gladiator tour”. Brought us to the arena floor via a different gate that the gladiators used. The colosseum was great…don’t get me wrong…but it didn’t take my breath away like the one in Verona did. THAT one was so incredibly amazing imo. When I come with my husband in May we’ll book a tour (again) because he is really wanting see it but I think we’ll do the night time, underground one
I booked with them.
Just don't carve your initials ANYWHERE in ITALY.
If this is your top gotta see, do it and don’t leave any venue unturned in Rome!

Our experience with the Colosseum yesterday was....our guide was excellent and very passionate about her knowledge but she was very very hard to understand. To the point that we missed a lot of info. We just did the arena and as huge as it is, there really wasn't much to see. It all looks the same. I was told after our tour that the underground is the way to go.

Going to Rome at the end of September. Staying for 3 days/
nights. Want to do skip the line and private tour of the Vatican, colleseum, catacombs. Any recommendations on who to use and any other suggestions like a ghost tour?

Arena floor and underground guided tour. It was fabulous and loads of information.
We booked through Get your guide
The Tour Guy guided tour with colosseum, Palestine hill and Roman forum so worth it! We did not go to the arena or gift shop but so interesting! We felt like we learned and saw so much!
Do an underground guided tour. It is fascinating, a must see. When in Rome....
The first Sunday of the new month entry is free 👍.Also most attractions
just go online 30 days before you want to go; tix are released all day long you will get what you need; just refresh and be patient;
On our Rome in a day tour we did the upper level but were left to wander when finished. We went down to the arena and took the pics. All tours will talk about everything so wouldnt worry about that.

My 18 year old daughter went to Italy on a school trip in 2022 and we went this summer. With school they did not do the arena floor. She told me that the main thing she wanted to do on our trip was to see the Arena floor because she felt like she had missed so much. After we did it, she told me it was so much more meaningful by including the floor + having a guided tour.

text:
Hi Italian lovers
My husband and I are travelling to Italy in September and October this year and decided to be spontaneous regarding accommodation and travel. But seeing all the posts about booking months or even a year in advance makes me think. Should I freak out? We are in our 50s and 60s and are not the type of people who like to plan ahead asआणखी we feel it is limiting our flexibility. Ok, looking forward to all your replies confirming me we ll still be able to catch trains and won't have to sleep on the streets 🤣🤩🙏💕

Edit: thanx everyone for sharing your thoughts and experiences. I have now gotten a good understanding and decided to turn off commenting 🙏💕

comments.comment_text: Just book your accommodation thru booking.com with free cancellation.

I went to Italy this year for a month rented a sprinter van had the time of my life, had very little plans loved places I’ve never heard of it was amazing parked outside the huge cities and taxied in;-)
Look at Expedia etc we just finished booking different hotels for September , lots of hotels but start doing it
What type of places do you look for? Chain hotel, smaller hotels, AirBnB?

We just got home from a round trip. I didn't book anything in advance, we decided in the morning which direction we were going, I usually booked the accommodation on the booking website in the afternoons. So, go ahead :-)
I haven’t booked any accomodation for Italy in October/ November. Having said that I have booked Greece and Turkey for September.

Last year, the second week of September, my neighbor and I were just getting to know each other and she and I decided that we both wanted to go to Italy. We booked our flights four weeks out and started to piece together two itineraries that started together in Sorrento, then took each of us to two separate parts of Italy, and brought us back together in Rome for our last four days the first week of November. We had no issues finding accommodations,
tours, ferries, or trains, a month in advance, or when unexpected things came up or opportunities presented themselves, on the spur of the moment. She was 59 and I was 70 years old at the time. Aside from the tours of major attractions (which you may or may not be interested in), our experiences would indicate you have little to worry about. Book the big things first and don't worry about planning every single detail way ahead. Leave room for some spontaneity. Meanwhile, that was my friend's first trip abroad and now she is about to start a yearlong world wide travel odyssey on her own which she has outlined for about 6 months but will book as she goes knowing that she will have more flexibility as to what exactly she wants to do once she is in each country.
I wouldn’t risk it. It could be disastrous.

Word of advise. I am a ta and I have clients that are doing Italy also same time as you. They can't find hotel availability so now they are calling me to find something for them. Unfortunately it seems eveything is going to Italy in the same time frame. Good luck!

Last year i travelled Italy from May-October. Peak season. Just like you i was spontaneous. Never had any problem get great accommodation, hotels/
apartments on the day or even 1-2 days before.
As for train tkts, the earliest i booked was the evening before, most of the time while walking to the train station. Trains are going every 10-20 min between the big cities. Never had a problem with either
Enjoy

Not sure if someone else posted this, but...

Maybe book cancellable accommodations.
That way, if you love where you are you can be flexible. Having just jammed in way too much in a short period of time, I highly recommend keeping the same accommodations for at least three nights and doing day trips from the same hub, rather than always being on the move with luggage.

Also, book the "big stuff" that you would be sad to miss out on. If you don't care about any of it, just go with the flow and you'll be happy with the flexibility.

I don't THINK trains will be a problem, but I defer to experts. I saw prices go up from when I first planned, so I think if you are again flexible, it's less of an issue, but if you don't want to miss a morning somewhere, book in advance.

Might need to book your accommodation. The Ryder Cup is on in Rome during that time
We booked accommodation ages ago 😊
We often book spontaneously if flights are cheap and we fancy a few days in Italy.

You’ll be fine. We do trips on a whim all the time to foreign countries. We always find accommodations & I have 5 people in my family. You can easily find accommodations for just 2. My go to app is booking . com & there is always something avail on there. Just try to book at least 24-36 hours in advance.
We went in October rented a car no tours basically did our own thing it was the best trip ever

That is what my husband and i are doing now. We are I our early 40's and trying to stay around €150/night. We have booked at least two of our hotels/air bnbs as we were on the train headed to the town. We have a general itinerary for which towns we wanted to be at on what dates, but we have changed that up a bit as we go. We are having a great time and have not had trouble finding places to stay. We check reviews and pick the best rated ones that meet our needs. Hostles are a last resort and we have not had to do that yet. (Two weeks in) It's not always perfect but we are quite happy!
We only book our accommodation and make plans as we go

We went for the whole of last October
Did not book
Some places are about to close for winter and will be glad to have you

That’s the only way we travel. We book our first night when we arrive and our last night before we return home. In between we map out where we want to go. We rent a car and book our hotels or B&B’s as we go. Great adventure and have been doing this for 35 years. Never had a problem. Going to Sicily in November and doing the same thing.
Hostels are fun!

Sept Oct being world cup months
No ways
Dont risk it!
Many hotels already over booked

We’re going for 3 weeks sept/oct. Haven’t booked anything yet except for the flights there and back. I’ll book accommodation in the next few weeks but trains when we’re there. Been doing it that way for 40 yrs! All part of the adventure! Enjoy and don’t worry.
Suggest you investigate accom on Booking.com just to get a sense of availability and prices for you dates. I just checked what we’d booked for Sept and prices have risen.
Be spontaneous!!! It’s the best experience
I would do this somewhere like America but not sure if it works in Italy ! I booked at least 6 months in advance

If money is no object then more power to you! We had to book everything 6 mos in advance after shopping around and researching tours. Drivers are extremely expensive! One thing is that renown restaurants with cliffside views in Positano/
Amalfi Coast were booked way in advance and we're such huge fancy foodies! I'd at least find plane tickets now unless your dates are flexible. Either way you choose, i believe some sort of stress exists. But it's all in the ways you chose to look at things. Wishing you the best time ever!!!

I’m in my 50’s and my husband in his 60’s. We just did our first trip ever and only booked Rome and Paris. The rest was by the seat of our pants. We rock backpacks and traveled on all sorts of transportation.
We mostly stayed in Airbnb booked the day before we arrived. We went for 3 months and only just got back. It’s crowded and busy but if you’re not expecting 5 star you can always find a place. We also stuck to a very tight budget
Family of 5 travelling in Sept/Oct too. Organising only some of our accommodation this coming weekend. We don’t like being locked in to too much either.
Depends on where you are going. The season officially ends 31 October so busy until then

I’m travelling through Italy now without any plans, and it has not been any issues getting accommodation anywhere. I only use Google maps when I arrive in a location, and there are always a lot of hotels and privat rentals to choose between. I have never traveled without plans earlier, but this has been a great experience 😊
In one of our trips to Italy, we never booked in advance. Every new town we got, we found a place to stay upon arrival. It was fun!
I suggest you book the first few days at least. I like to know where im going to sleep
September 28-October 1 is the Ryder Cup in Rome. Hotels that week seem to be very crowded. They golf tournament could bring in 50k people per day
We booked trains, coaches night before. Day trip of Rome the day before. You dont need to forward plan BUT it will help you to enjoy your time more when in Italy
Why don’t you book accom with free cancellation as a back up?
Sounds adventurous. I'm also traveling with a group late Sept/early Oct. In particular, the Ryder Cup is in Rome 9/25-Oct 1 so finding accommodations near there may be more challenging. Enjoy!

For a trip like that you need to plan way in advance for your accommodations and tours. But, ive always been a planner for at least flights and accommodations.
Good luck on finding a great place to stay.

I think Italy is less busy in those months,so you won’t need to book everything in advance,pre covid I travelled in October,arrived
in Rome at night and the day after I left for Assisi,I went to termini around 10am to buy the train ticket for 2pm train…still available and still inexpensive

I also booked the hotel in Rome and Loreto around a week before

Everything is more expensive last minute. It's easier on the hosts if they know who is coming. Train pricing is dynamic and last minute tickets are more expensive than advance purchase. Maybe look at a Eurail pass for flexible train but pre-book a few cancellable rooms so you can cancel if plans change.
Our trip is August 2024 and here we are planning already the reason why I am here. Everyone being helpful so far thank you.
The quality if lodging won't be ideal.

If you find flights and hotels…everythi
ng else can be spontaneous
I’m going in October, and if you want to stay in a particular area I would book as it is busy all the time since Covid. I was in Italy this year in February (winter) and was busy🌻

We book out months in advance but use hotels.com or booking.com. We have never had an issue and used them for years. We choose accommodations that are fully refundable until a few days before the actual check in date. This gives us the flexibility to cancel if needed. Also sometimes better options pop up as people may cancel. This holds a place for us and we can cancel if needed!
We are going in sept/beg October and I we have struggled with the accommodations we wanted- definitely busier this year after the typical tourist season.

I think it’s important to book the first couple of nights in advance so that you are certain to be okay those initial days. After that, once you’re there, do whatever your heart desires. I bet you’ll be fine

As a traveler that hates to be hauled around in a mob of people on a tour or have every second planned, I’m totally with you in allowing room for spontaneity. Personally I think many people don’t take the time to just be and soak up the culture.
I wish you all the best. It seems half the world is in Italy at the moment. I’ve been booking for a year.
I would not want to spend precious time in Italy looking on a phone to find a place when I could have done it before I left home.

The longer you wait, the less selection and more expensive. We have booked hotels, then watched the rates go up significantly with each passing month. As soon as we book our flights we decide on an itinerary and then start looking at lodging. Usually about 10 months out. We are booked for next spring and some of the Air B& B's have an "early bird discount"... and other bookings already. As soon as train schedules are released, we book those (usually two - three months out).

You may find places to stay but my only concern is that the best spots may be booked out and you will have to 'settle' for a lumpy bed in a dodgy location for the night. You may also find yourself spending half your travel day googling/
walking to find your next accommodation, particularly in the popular locations. I would book at least where you need 2+ nights and try to wing the rest. Enjoy your trip.
At the very least have the first few days accommodations reserved!
Hotels were the first thing I booked, I then built the trip around that. I wanted to stay in specific areas. I did middle of the line as far as pricing went.
I’m going in October for a month and still haven’t booked all my accommodation but when I do book I have been able to find numerous options

When I travel, I usually plan the “big events”. Flights, certain hotels/
hostels, rental cars etc. But I let a lot fly. I got an awesome room in Sicily for €36 the day off. Right by the beach.

It’s great to be spontaneous if everyone agrees and are able to make decisions quickly. We like to have an itinerary as a starting point and give ourselves the flexibility to deviate. Nothing worse than everyone staring at each other trying to figure out what to do, where to eat etc. because they haven’t considered the options ahead of time.
We just returned from Luca and Montepulciano. No reservations u til the night before we arrived. Had a blast. We are in our late 60s. Go for it.
Anybody know how busy Rome is after Christmas

Going to Italy in September. I am a planner. Booked our hotel in Hilton Sorrento last year and was able to get good rates. I love to research and plan in advance to get good deals. I opted to have a private transfer from Rome to Sorrento and found this company that gave us a good deal. I also booked our tours directly from Hilton Sorrento. Booked our train from Naples to Florence and booked our tour for one night then will take the train to Rome before heading back home. Hope and pray all goes well.
We have been booking for the last 6 months but doing two other countries as well as Italy

I'm heading to Naples in mid-October. I have been tracking accommodation. A lot has gone. The very specific area I want to be in had a load of options 2-3 months back. Now the options are all a bit away from transport. so it adds to the hassle. I have a place booked with free cancellation but I still look as I'm always after the best location, price, and vibe. I would book TBH, or you'll end up paying for more expensive places, which may be Ok for you or not, and places less convenient. I have also booked a long-distance fast train. On several timed services when I specifically wanted to go there were not many seats available. Again, if you want to maximise your convenience then book ahead. If you're happy to rock up and catch whatever, then you can wait. I am like you and like to be flexible. For some things, it's just less hassle big picture-wise to book.
I always travel spur of the moment I only book first night and last night and fill it in as we go along toured Puglia just this May no problems
I planned my detailed trip to Italy with my teenaged daughter last month after deciding to go just 4 weeks prior. It all worked out perfectly!
I never book in advance.
Just consider….. You will pay more booking at the last minute.

If you don’t have hotel rooms, good luck. We started booking in June for italy/Sicily in September/
October and had a hell of a time finding good accommodations.
I book the 1st few days, and then a day or two before I move to a different location. Sometimes I arrive in a place and walk into hotels, look at the rooms and then decide. Never "freak-out".
A lot of hotels offer free cancellation, that works well in case your plans change allowing flexibility while also securing a place to stay.

I spent 11 weeks in Europe this year. I only booked a week or so in advance to create flexibility in travel plans. I had no problems. I would never book that far in advance. I like to be able to adjust my trips based on being able to make last minute changes. Been doing thus for 40+ years without issues on 4 continents
Ryder Cup on Rome and Fashion Week in Milan. I'm traveling the same time frame as you.
If you are very flexible in terms of when, how AND where, no problem!

We are In Slovakia now and have been traveling for two months now. We have general plans but nothing booked. It has given us freedom to change plans as we go. We are in our 60s and found it to be very easy. We have a car so that gives us even more freedom. It is super easy to find accommodations on the internet.
We fly to Italy in 3 weeks and only booked about 6 weeks ago....
You will always find something available on booking.com, but it might not be exactly where or what you want.

Hi, it looks like you don’t have an itinerary, therefore should be easy to find accommodations.
If you want to visit Venice book a hotel in Vicenza, only half hr away from Venice by train & half the price. If you want to see Florence but you can’t find a place to stay go to Siena or even Bologna. Trains are so convenient to travel with…You should be fine in Rome, is a big city but just in case… we stayed at the Memphis Hotel very clean and central. Have fun…:))

I’m sure you’ll be fine but likely won’t have the choices you might have had if you had booked in advance, so possibly more steps to climb, lack of AC, further from city center, etc. and you may not be able to find space on the fast trains, so you might have to take the regional ones. It really comes down to your comfort level and flexibility.
I'm in my seventies and I wing it. Not much help, I know, but no need to panic. Travel light.

Only my humble opinion but tourism has increased greatly in Italy since the pandemic, I would have a reservation in place for at least the first few nights so you aren't scrambling. Then, decide the rest while you're there.
Don't worry. You'll be fine. No need to book in advance.

September is the new Summer. Quite busy. October thins out. I book lodging (and still tweak) early in my planning mainly because I’m selective of where I stay (location, style, price, but above all…experience)
. If you’re good with simply cleanliness, you’ll have no problem finding a decent place. Spontaneous travel is a mindset! I use booking dot com religiously for lodging. Sounds fun! Enjoy!!

This post gives me major anxiety! Ha! I’m such a planner. We are going first 2 weeks in October, and have been booking since February.
Good luck!
You can always find a hotel room near an airport or train station.
Put your faith in God and you will have a roof over your head❤️❤️🎶
Go for it! Book as you normally do, you’re sure to find accommodation where you want to stay. Happy hols!
We go to Sorrento every year and have to book a year in advance. It’s very popular.

September and October are popular months for travel to Italy. Especially September. But October was still fairly crowded when I was there last year. Especially in Rome. If you are planning on going to popular spots you should book in advance. Otherwise you may find nothing available or rooms that are less than desirable
Depends if you have your heart set on specific things/places, most overplanners do.
I would book accommodations for sure!
Honestly, I hate traveling with an itinerary. It’s not like you are traveling with an entourage.

16 of us showed up in Rome 2 weeks ago to receive an email the Air B&B had double booked on the morning we arrived. Fortunately we found alternate accommodation in the middle of Rome to fit all 16 of us.
You will always find accomodation- but if you have a particular place in mind and it’s popular book it - been booking for a trip in 2024 and already a couple of places booked out.
I went on a spontaneous trip last september. Had no issues finding bookings. Stayed at Ibis
All the good places book quickly so you may have tro6ble with the spontaneous approach. But if you get a base for the duration and travel from there you can be more spontaneous or flexible.
I just booked my trains 2 days in advance.... But then I was not in Rome, Florence ect as everyone here appears to be. I had no problem in late June.

Spontaneous & flexibility is great & I likely would not book a year ahead myself, but I would definitely start booking now for a trip that is 2 months away. We just googled & read reviews, but that was pre-COVID. It seems last year & this year have been travel on steroids 🤣. A post just today gave recs for several air bnb’s.
Good luck & HAVE FUN!
Living in Italy, every time I decide to... go to Italy I book at the last minute, and always find a place to stay 😆
You are more adventurous than me. We are there August and September and have had our accommodation booked for 9 months. Enjoy you trip!
How refreshing - travel is such a wonderful adventure. The best travel experiences I’ve done and those from which I’ve learned most have been the ones with the least amount of fore planning.

We've spent 40 years traveling spontaneously and have never had a big problem. Small problems from time to time but never big. We've lways found a room but we go in the off season...April or October.....don
't what it would be like in August. We only line up rooms ahead of time for the first and last nights.

I think you can travel.
Without reservations in October. But you definitely will need them in september

Italy is HOT and I don’t mean temperature. I love the serendipity of travel but I only get a little each year due to Hubbys position and I don’t want to miss the big sites because I did not plan and there are no tickets left. It took me 3 trips to France to see Versailles and 3 to London for crown 👑 jewels due to precious poor planning. I am to old to
Go back everywhere to see things I missed! I don’t want to be stuck waiting for a train for most of the day because I didn’t plan. Also I like day tours and private tours. Need to plan for these too. The flexibility comes from the unscheduled time in each day on my trips.
We were in Italy in July and parts of our trip were flexible. We booked some Rome accomodation while we were on the bus & 30 minutes before we arrived. They were also discounted.
Depending of where you want to stay ! I would book now and plan … small b&b the ones that makes you save money they fill up quickly. Hotels with many rooms they will have space but more expensive.
Dean Stanmore

I am normally a very spontaneous traveler and will book hotels as we are driving to the next city lol but I started looking and the hotels looked rough price wise so I booked what I could this time around! We are going mid august though so super crowded time frame.
Maybe book a hotel for your first night only? That way you know you have a place to sleep after a day of travel.

Italy this year is seeing a tremendous increased demand for tourism! However, if you can narrow down where you want to stay and for how long that would increase probability in finding accommodations.
If you’re looking at lesser visited destinations your in better position to find accommodations-
and booking train tickets for popular destinations might be a problem- but I think that part can be worked out.

I’d like to tell you everything will be fine. But honestly I can’t. There was a time in the past where I traveled spontaneously without hotel reservations. (I’m fact I did it for a full three month time period once.) But the reality in these days of mass tourism can make that very difficult. You might be able to find spur of the moment accommodations but depending on your particular destinations it’s more likely that you won’t. It’s also probable that the few available rooms will be at the extreme edges where fewer people travel. Either the bottom level, cheapest places where most people do not want to stay or the highest priced luxury ones that most people can’t afford could be your only options. You could easily be faced with the choice between a dingy, dilapidated. dirty room or one that costs a few thousand dollars a night. With the third possibility that there might be no room at the inn at all. To me that’s just very stressful.

I’d suggest formulating a general itinerary that includes the number of nights you think you’ll need in each location. I’d book a room in those places but leaving the days unscheduled to have some flexibility in exploring. Of course that runs the risk that you might not be able to gain admission to a few attractions, especially in the more popular destinations, but that’s easier to deal with than not finding a hotel room and might strike a good balance between over planning and spontaneity.

I know from experience that spontaneity doesn’t feel so great when you can’t find a place to lay your weary head at night.

As far as trains we’ve driven for the past 30 plus years so I haven’t taken the trains in ages. But I know many routes require reserved seats now. So that might be something to consider, too.

Wishing you luck!
I would start looking now. The longer you wait the less options available and the more expensive
Book your first week and take if from there, I travelled 3 months in Italy last year and only booked my next lot of accommodation the day before I left.

You would be more than okay. We actually did it yesterday in Rimini, walked into the hotel and booked the room, and it was cheaper than it was a month ago when we thought about booking it. Same 10 days ago in Turin. Have a fantastic time 🙂

I have never seen Italy as busy as this year it's as though the whole world has decided to holiday there. We only booked Sorrento accommodation in March for May. In June I booked our Lucca accommodation in February but booked as and when we decided on our next destination, Florence, Milan and Genoa were booked a couple of days before. Same with trains and a flight home.

Tourism is up dramatically everywhere in Europe. I would not risk not finding a spot (check previous posts on people not be able to find accommodations when canceled), so I would at least book cancellable reservations in advance. Then you can search around if your plans change. You can wing it for the trains and some tourist attractions.

If you're not on a tight budget, I don't see any problem. However, good accommodations get fully booked early for a reason. The mediocre and bad places are what's left over, and there's a chance you will end up paying last-minute high prices for them.
I think you'll be fine. We actually just had to add on a night to one of our stays this past weekend in Pompeii and had no trouble. It's really nice not to be locked down to a time schedule.
Last October my husband and I only had a one way ticket to Rome. We stayed 5 days then decided where to next. And next after that until we decided to fly home. It was the most fun we ever had.

I’m just gonna be completely candid with you.

You’re going to the most popular international destination in the world.

During ￼wine crush.

And you’re expecting to find accommodations easily.

You probably will, but you’re going to pay out the nose for it.
And it won’t be nearly the level of accommodation and service you expect.
Or the experience that others who planned ahead are having.

I think your obsessive need to be adventurous and not plan anything is a little ridiculous.

When people tell me they had a bad time in Italy, this is usually how it starts

The best hotels are already sold out for Sept and Oct.
Depending on where you're going and what your budget flex is like. . for example, I booked Amalfi, as accommodation in my price range & my "musts" (under $500/nt) was almost NIL.

Hi! I am here now, solo. I booked about 3-4 weeks out and have been very pleased with my accommodations.
Go for it!

Normally I book far in advance with Airbnb, but while in Rome a couple weeks ago I decided to rent a car for a few days and check out some of the smaller towns/villages in Lazio. I winged it on the hotels and had no problem at all. The first ones I went to in both Orvieto and Tivoli had availability and both were right around 90€ a night, which I didn’t think was bad given the season and their locations.

text:
Boungiorno!!
I just returned from a 3 week trip which included 11 days in Italy and to pay it forward, I will share my experience, what worked and didn't work. We flew non-stop Miami-Zurich. Visited family and then flew ITA Zurich to Rome.

ROME
We arrived from Switzerland, a Schengen country, so for anyone wondering, there is no need to go through passport control once in the Schengen region. We traveled this leg of the trip COO and personal bag.

We had a private transfer prebooked for 60 Euros which took us from FCO to the hotel in the area of the Pantheon.

Weather-hot, but manageable. The first few days in Rome were delightful. Last day got into the 90s but only 28% humidity, so this FL girl was fine. Clocked on average 20-21K steps daily.

Roma is busy, crowded, dusty and WONDERFUL!!

-Vatican (early admission with breakfast). Booked directly through the official website. By 7:30, the lines were long including the skip-the-line line, which moves fairly fast once the third party tours go in. If you book directly, there is a separate line with no wait, as they let you in up to 15 minutes prior to the timed ticket. There is another line inside to exchange your voucher for actual tickets. That moved fairly fast.

-Saint Peter's Basilica- the lines are long to get in. If you go to the Vatican Museum you can go in after the Sistine Chapel. We didn't, (my mom was done walking at that point :) )so we decided to go the next morning. No lines early. By the time we left the lines were incredibly long (although they move fairly fast). We had the Basilica almost to ourselves for a while. Within a couple of hours, everyone was on top of each other. While there, visited the Grotto.
I attempted to get tickets to the Scavi ahead of the trip by wasn't able to secure them within the time we had available -one excuse to go back.

When visiting the Basilica, make sure you have tops that cover your shoulders and your dress is below the knees. I wore long wide-legs pants and short sleeves to make it easy. (otherwise you have to drape the blue cover over you! not fun in a hot day)

-Trevi. We visited it a few times (since we were so close to it). It was busy, but plenty of room for photo ops. Everyone, except the instragram divas, was very polite and accommodating and moved out of the way to let others have their pictures.

-Pantheon. Get tickets ahead of time. You will still wait in line, but only with the people with tickets for that hour (they are 1 hr time slots ie. 10-11, 2-3, etc, not timed exactly). The lines for tickets were long. One for cash, one for CCs. They wrapped around, even at 9AM. We had tickets for the first hour they opened.

-Golf Cart tour. We booked through Rolling Rome. Eduardo was AMAZING! we had seen some of the attractions so I asked him to take us to his favorite places in Rome. He obliged, including his favorite gelato place. Oh my! don't miss Neve di Latte! Amazing. It was a private tour, so we had the freedom to go places away from the typical route.

-Colosseum. We had booked an underground/arena tour through LivTours. The underground portion was cancelled a few weeks before we left, so they rebooked us in a semi-private tour that included everything else. Our guide was magnificent. We had a blast and he even explained portions of what we could see of the underground. There was only one other family with us with two young boys and he was very attentive to them and really took the time with them and my mom (83 y/o). I cannot imagine doing the Colosseum in a large group. If you can, go for private or semi-private tours.... or try to get tickets directly from Coopculture.it.
BTW, it was hot, but there is plenty of shady spots so we didn't have much of an issue (but remember, I'm from Florida :) )

-Roman Forum/Palatine Hill. We got tickets to visit on our own. We had the Super Forum tickets and the extra money is well worth it. There are a few extra sites that are simply amazing. We really enjoyed Santa Maria Antiqua with Oratorio. (Plus they are nice and cool and offer a break in the heat if traveling in the summer)

-We visited several churches, including Santa Maria Maggiore. Enjoyed several galleries but mostly spent the free time sightseeing and exploring Rome. Five days were not enough.

FLORENCE
The city is simply amazing! The art oozes out of every building. Being in the architectural and design field, I was in heaven!

-Ufizzi. It's a most. But plan for at least 4 hours. There is so much to see and we didn't get to finish it -and that wasn't even stopping to read a lot. We didn't have a tour, so we took our time, and breaks and then ran out of time LOL. We were there 3 hours and missed a few areas. We will return.

-The Accademia. We had 8:15 tickets. There were only a handful of people inside and we got to spend as much time as we wanted visiting David and the rest of the gallery. By the time we left (about 1 1/2 hours later) the crowds inside were quite large and outside the line wrapped around the corner. Get tickets. There are lines with the time and you just line up in the correct time slot. It's easy. It's also wheelchair friendly -if you are traveling with someone a little tired (like my mom :) )

-We had tickets to the Duomo's complex. If you want to get inside the church itself, you must get there early. It's free but the lines are long. The Baptistery is under renovations, so you can see the walls but not the actual baptistery (another excuse to go back!)

-Palazzo Ricardi Medici is small, but worth a visit. You don't need tickets ahead of time. It can be visited in an hour.

There were other attractions, all worth visiting. (The view from Michaelangelo Piazza is gorgeous) We only had 3 1/2 days in Florence and felt that we covered a lot of ground just walking around, but will definitely would love to spend more time visiting Ufizzi and Palazzo Vecchio.

Side trip to PISA.

This was planned at the last minute. Took the local train from Florence to Pisa at 5PM. It was crowded, hot and a true 'local' experience.

There are a few interesting sights in PISA including the main attraction -the leaning tower. But all took about a couple of hours to visit.

After that, we strolled away from the touristy area and came to a really nice restaurant, where we had an amazing dinner.

Took the train back to Florence and arrived close to midnight. All in all, it was a great side trip, never to come back again. (But I recommend a visit at least once. The architectural details and history of the tower are worth visiting and seeing)

MILAN
We were here 2 days. Visited the main attractions, including the Duomo, Gallery and a little shopping :)

This city has more of a 'European' vibe. It reminded me a lot of Boston (USA) in some ways (for reference, I lived in Boston for 32 years). The old and the new coexisting.

From here, we took the train to Bern. It was Ciao Italy. Until next time.

As general notes:

Restaurants - we only made one reservation for dinner in Rome, and although excellent, not the highlight of the culinary experience.

May not be a popular opinion here, but most restaurants ARE open during the afternoon. We encountered only one that was open for drinks and just crossed the street to 3 that were open.

We had gelato every.single.day. :) in all cities. We visited Scudieri quite a bit while in Florence as they were closest to our hotel, but we just didn't have one bad gelato anywhere. Same for meals. Unplanned, unscheduled, totally worth the flexibility. You won't starve in Italy.

Bathrooms - never paid to use a single toilet room.
Pisa was the most challenging one as it was inside McDonals at the train station and it was dirty and could go in only by punching a code printed on a receipt from them. My code didn't work, so a few of us went in when someone came out.
The Roman forum toilet rooms (we used 4 of them) were clean, but out of toilet paper, but I learned in this group to take the ends of rolls with me everywhere. Only had to use them there. Thank you to whoever suggested that!!

Trains - we travelled high speed Frecciarossa from Rome to Florence and Florence Milan. Fairly inexpensive and super convenient. We had booked tickets ahead of time, so perhaps that made a difference. We travelled Business Class and then first class on the train to Bern.
You need to find the train number on the board. A few minutes before the scheduled time, they will post the platform. You need to hurry up if you have a slow walker :)

Taxis - No issues in Rome. Our hotel or restaurant would call them and they always showed up on time, and no one tried to 'scam' us. They are harder to come by in Florence. It was a bit of a challenge on day, but we managed to find one eventually.

The rates are higher on Sunday. Just be aware of that.

Finally, what to wear.
Stop obsessing about what to wear. My dress style is relaxed casual. (not torn anything...:). I took what I wear at home. (I live in a tourist town, surrounded by tourists... :) )
Most of what I took had shoulders (no spaghetti straps, etc) so I didn't have to worry too much about going into churches. Having said all that, people wear what they want! You are on vacation. Enjoy your favorite style and go with it. Be comfortable. You will never be like the locals. They dress nicely. But they are also not out and about all day. Dress nice, but comfortable -whatever that means for you- and you will be fine. No one cares.

Things I took that were MUSTS.
-Laundry detergent sheets and universal sink plug. Too much gelato meant a few stains. Plus it allowed us to keep up with washing a couple of tops in the sink.

-Portable fan. This was a life-saver. Italians (Europeans in general) have no concept of COLD AC LOL. All our hotels had good AC, and 2 of them didn't have the card on the controls, so they could run all day if we wanted to. Still they never felt cold enough for me, so having the little fan was the ticket!

-Hairdryer and Conditioner. This girl has to have her hairdryer, so I have one that is for travel only (not dual voltage, but 240v). Hotels have them, but not strong enough for my hair. Also none of the hotels had conditioner.

-Comfortable shoes. I mostly wore my Aetrex sneakers, a pair of Aetrex sandals for 'dressier ocassions' and Vionic sneakers. My feet didn't hurt or got tired even with all the walking we did.

-Linen. You will thank me later. Wrinkles and all. Stylish and comfortable.

-Euros. We took about 500 with us. CC are accepted everywhere, but we left tips in hotels, tour guides, etc. and also used cash for small purchases. We found that some places wouldn't even have small change for cash purchases.

Things that I didn't use
-Rain jacket. It won't make the trip next time (unless it's in the 'rainy season'. Didn't take a whole lot of room, but totally unused. There is plenty of cover or you can buy a cheap umbrella is needed.

-I used all the outfits I took, but some more than others. What seems cute at home (or even in Switzerland/France), were not the most comfortable ones in Italy. Again, linen is king.

-Selfie stick. Can't use in some museums and if we wanted group pictures, we just asked another tourist to take ours in exchange for taking theirs. It was fine, but also we were a party of 3 (in Rome) and 4 in Florence.

-Hydration packs. Just drink plenty of water. Save the agony of the taste and weight they add. There are water fountains everywhere.

Last words
Go with the flow! We had not major issues. We carried our passports EVERYWHERE. Did not need them once, including getting on the trains. I had a medium size travelon crossbody with a passport pouch inside attached to the bag where I kept cash and passport.

We never saw pickpocketing, but I also didn't take the metro or busses (except to Pisa). I kept the bag in front of my body and used a lanyard for my phone. It came in handy as I almost dropped it a couple of times.

I know this has been a long post. If you are still reading, I hope you found it helpful! Most of all, ENJOY ITALY!!! It's wonderful. Relax, have fun and most importantly, plan a trip back! I'm already working on it. 😍

text: Can I convert US cash to euros when I arrive? I do not have an atm card.

comments.comment_text: I didn’t have a debit/atm card before our trip. My bank was able to print one for me on the spot. (I also had my bank order me euros to take with me. Took like 2 days.)
I'd get a debit card.....I always travel with 3 cards in different places. But yes you can exchange money but you pay to do so.

Here is our recent experience in Rome, with exchanging currency

$1,000.00 to Euros
exchange rate .94 /1.06.
Newark Airport €830.00
Rome airport €726.00
Roma train station €820.00
Across from train station, €875.00
In front of train station by snack bar
€900.00

If you feel the need to have euros the moment you land, only get a small amount at the airport. Wait until you get into the city and go to a ATM at an actual bank, they will charge less fees and have a better conversion rate. The airports and train stations are a rip off.

Using a credit card that doesn’t charge international fees, is the best way to go.

I got a Visa travel money card from my bank. Just load it with enough for your trip. Really easy. I also purchased Euros from my bank before my trip so I had cash for think like taxis, buses and gelato! 😊
I went to a money exchange to change Dollars to Euros in Venice. It was not pretty what I got for my $400.
Get an atm card before you go and credit card without exchange cost
Yes but I would do it here!

Change here at your bank as much as you think you will need. You should do at least a week before you go. We had a hard time in Greece looking for places to exchange & then we paid a fee. Also we used credit cards as well

Yeah but it will cost you more.

You’re better off with a credit card doing the exchange. See if your card has foreign transaction fees. If not use that card for everything.

Just prepay the card before you leave or while you’re on your trip.
Get it from your bank before you leave
And get an ATM card 😂
It’s a pain - get a card .

For anyone who hasn’t done their trip yet: do not take US cash and then exchange it once you are in Europe- this has gone the way of the traveller’s cheques, and I mean this in the nicest way possible. It is much easier and cheaper to just withdraw cash from an ATM that belongs to a bank ( not one of those freestanding ones you see at the airport or in shops etc)

I like to have some euro when I leave home and my bank has them so I just pick them up a few days before, then I use ATMs and my credit card. My bank has an arrangement with different banks overseas so I don’t pay ATM fees when I use overseas ATMs - check your bank to see if they have this arrangement.
Get an ATM card. I don’t know why you don’t have one, seriously.
Get a Wise card and transfer your local currency in and convert to Euro. Draw out as cash (fee free limitations) or pay as a credit card.
Get them before you go. The exchange rate at the airport is terrible. I think it was 1.34 per euro vs. my bank which was 1.09.
If you're in the US, you can get euros at Triple A as well (if your bank doesn't offer it )
Get an ATM card. Period

Get Euros at AAA. NO FEE GOOD EXCHANGE RATE or at your bank here.
If you have no debit card I assume you have a credit card. A little difficult to check into hotel without a card.
If you are taking a few thousand dollars keep it in the safest place possible.
You will usually pay a large fee in the money exchange stores or at airport. You loose big time.

Try Wise
Get a Travel Money card fantastic accepted nearly all places we’ve been over 8 weeks in Europe just drew out small amount of cash for really little things 👍

Who is your bank? Most can get euros for you before you depart. The exchange rate is usually much better here.

Get a Revolut card to use just for your trip.
Took about a week to receive mine in the mail. You can swap currencies in your account.
Before you leave. Do you have a credit card? Best to charge most meals, tours to that in local currency Keep cash for tips, small snacks, busses etc
Yes but rather do it before you leave
Do not do at airport. I lost 80 changing 300 to euros
I went to my local bank and they ordered Euros for me
I didn’t Bring enough. I am in Spain for two weeks before going to Italy. I’m actually trying to find where to get more in Spain. Most places take cards but small mom and pops and boutiques don’t.

Use credit cards to buy anything that you buy or when you eat in restaurants the credit card companies will give you a good exchange rates when your bill comes use cash only for small items
