text:
Looking to plan a 10 day trip- need some help- want to start in rome for a quick day then head to amalfi coast - positano- naples- capri- sorrento and end in milan. Can someone help or tell me best way to do this?

Do I stay at one location and just take ferry to all those places or stay 2 days each location and change hotels?

comments.comment_text: I planned this whole trip out but ditched it haha. You’d want to take the train from Rome or fly into Naples. Then ferry to one of the ports on the amalfi coast… Sorrento is the closest. Then you can jump from sorrento to positano then Capri.

If you want to start from Amalfi coast, then you need to fly into NAP(Napoli) —> Molobeverello Port—> Ferry to Positano or Amalfi. If you are flying into FCO(Roma), then first you take a train to Roma Termini, take a high speed train to either Napoli Centrale or Salerno —> Ferry to either Amalfi or Positano.

Sorrento is a great base for ferry rides to Positano, Amalfi, Capri, and Napoli. Once your coastal/
island trips are finished, stay in Napoli. Take a high speed train up to Milano Centrale(roughly 4 ish hours).

Or use Napoli as a base and hit all the coastal destinations by ferry. If you choose rail system, Circumvesuviana
Sorrento Line will take you to Sorrento in 90 minutes.

If I were you, I would fly into Napoli, take a ferry straight to Capri, then another ferry to Positano or Amalfi, ferry to Sorrento, then Napoli.
In fact, just two months ago, we did exactly what I just described above except day trip to Positano while staying in Sorrento and omitted Amalfi
Train is super easy from Rome to Naples...then in Naples take the ferry to Capri and to the out sites...

We are about to do this trip. Starting in rome so we can fly direct, and the heading to Pompeii via Naples. Private car supposed to pick us up in Pompeii and take us to hotel in positano where we will be staying.
That’s a lot of ground to cover in only 10 days. Any particular reason you want to visit Milan? If it were me, I’d do Rome and the Amalfi coast and skip Milan.
I would go Rome - Naples then Sorrento (day trips to Positano, Capri & Ravello) then fast train Naples to Florence on to Bologna then Venice. Milan is fine but it is a big city and a bit soulless.
We are staying In Sorrento to do Capri island and Amalfi coast/ Positano

text: Hi fellow travellers. We’ll be in Milan, Venice, Florence, Rome and Sorrento over the next month and looking for an amazing Italian pasta cooking class in any of those cities. One that includes drinking, dancing and having a great time, any recommendations?
Do I need to buy train tickets in advance or can I buy them at the station?

comments.comment_text: You can buy at the station, don't forget to validate! Buying your ticket from your phone is the easiest I found!
You can buy them at the station or online
Italo and Frecce is better booking in advance to save money.

If you buy in advance and your flight is delayed then you are out of luck.
As soon as you know you are on time, book them on Omio
Much less expensive booked way in advance
No
I like to have all my documents in hand before I travel.
Trainline, easy to use, avoid long lines at station.

Regional trains : you can make ticket even One minute before.
Intercity and High Speed trains: you must make ticket to reserve place aboard.
At the station
You can buy at the station, but in general high speed trains are cheaper if booked ahead of time
At station. Give yourself time to buy them.

You can buy them at the station but make sure you know the exact station/city you are going, Iin Italy there are 2 systems, EuroRail and Italian Rail, make sure you know where you are going and which Rail you will need. Generally in Italy city to city will be Italian Rail and it will be Euro will be between countries.
Use the Trainline app and save all the hassles at a busy station and always prebuy in busy periods.

Beware of the station attendants that “help” you purchase your train tickets, check your tickets carefully as we had to pay an extra 100 Euros to return to Florence from Venice last fall to catch the only train. Our helper booked us an extended stay of a week, we never were able to recoup our loss as we were referred to their website to straighten things out. 🤬

text:
Hi there! Planning a 10th anniversary trip for my husband and I. Italy is our destination. We will have 7-8 nights (not including travel there/home).

We want to explore, eat amazing food, and soak up everything Italy has to offer. I know we can’t possibly see the entire country in that time. But could we reasonably explore Florence, Rome, and theआणखी Amalfi coast in that amount of time? How should we split it up? Should we eliminate one? We want to enjoy somewhat luxury accommodations as well.

Our anniversary is in March, but I’ve been told we should wait and go in May. Any merit to that?

We are so excited for this trip and I love planning, so send me all the tips and advice! 🙂

comments.comment_text:
Hi ! I am also planning an anniversary trip for my husband and I am planning fly into Rome and do 3 days, train to Florence and spend 3 nights and do a day trip Tuscany and then train Venice for a few days then fly home with maybe quick stop Paris , seems all flights Venice stop Paris way back anyway , nights as well spend a few days !
Good luck with your planning ! I’ll look forward to the comments on your post to help me as well !

Amalfi Peninsula is usually a four or five night stay. So save that for another trip. You can do a great trip to Florence Rome with Tuscany in between.. You will have a chance to drink some incredibly good wine. Enjoy. Absolutely go in may

I'm going next June. We're doing 4 nights in Florence, 2 nights in Amalfi, 3 nights in Rome. We're coming from a week in Switzerland so not able to do any longer. If we could, we would probably add an additional night in the Amalfi coast.

Hope this helps, enjoy your anniversary trip! 🙂❤️
If you are dead set on the Amalfi coast, yes, I would definitely wait until May. So gorgeous then!
ASP purchase Rick Steve’s Italy travel guide! And start watching all the wonderful utube videos about traveling Italy!
As an Italian that lives in Tuscany, for only 7 full days, Rome ( 4 days ) and Florence ( 3 days ) maybe a day trip to Pisa or Siena
We are going for my 40th birthday (leaving Saturday!!) and we are doing just that. Florence, Rome & Positano. I'm so excited.

We flew to Rome and did 2 days. We saw everything possible except Vatican City. We did a ton of walking with a baby. We took the train to sorrento and did the Amalfi coast for 7 days. 5-7 in Amalfi at least.
I haven’t been to Florence but I would probably do 2 nights Florence, 2 nights rome, 3 nights amalfi coast. Also depends what you want to do in each location 🙂
Hi , I’m flying into Rome but don’t want to stay there

Oops pressed the wrong button, I’ve been to Rome so we Want to do Venice, Florence and the Amalfi coast , my question is should I start in Venice and work my way to Florence and the the amlfi coast or do the coast first and then back to Venice.
I would split your time between Rome and the Amalfi Coast. Four days on the Amalfi Coast and three in Rome.
One night in Rome wouldn’t be worth it.

U will
Need to skip 1 for sure , for me 7-8 days is hardly enough for just Rome and a bit of Florence . Unless u do not need any side trip from Florence , I am doing 5 days in rome (and I do not think it is enough as Rome is far more than just the typical places ppl visit) Florence itself needs 2 full days (again more than just what ppl say u need to see) then there are at least 4 places not far from Florence u should visit , that also needs at least 2 whole days
I am looking at travelling to Sorrento and surrounds in early November. Is this a good time to visit?

For that amount of time I would suggest fly into Rome to arrive morning or midday stay at least three nights in Rome then choose either going to Florence or Almafi (depending how much you love the ocean) I would choose Almafi and go in May (though I loved Florence). We just spent 13 nights in Italy in May and it was awesome and yes rent a car (on the day you leave Rome) or hire a driver to take you to Almafi. We took a taxi $50 euros flat rate back to the airport first thing in the morning to rent a car and drove to Positano. Stayed in amazing Air bnb and had incredible dinner overlooking the water but be ready for a lot of stairs and hills. Parking was 50 euros a night in Positano. If you stay longer then add more places. We did 3 nights Rome, 1 night Pompei, 2 nights Positano, 1 night Florence, 2 nights Cinque Terre, 1 night Milan, 1 night Venice, 1 night Tuscany and that was a lot of travelling in a car and well planned out. I would go back and stay a week in Positano or a week in Tuscany. Whatever you choose will be great it just depends what you want to see so make a list of must sees then choose, you can’t go wrong but you can always go back to Italy again.
Definitely not enough time for all 3. What would you see in Rome for one day/night? Save Florence or Amalfi for another trip.

For a short stay and your want to see the most, I would recommend a tour. Trafalgar does an excellent job and you will not be disappointed. You will also have all the legwork done for you. Have a fantastic trip

text:
Are the seats in the main cabin on an American Airlines flight comfortable enough 4A 9 hour flight from Chicago to Rome?
Is it worth paying double for the premium seat?

comments.comment_text: I have paid my dues to life & family, now it’s me! I go best seat possible, get there like a human being, get treated beautifully. Yes, the cost was frkn crazy, my kids will get less inheritance, lol!
We flew Dallas to Dublin last year on American and we paid a little extra just to have extra legroom and that was absolutely worth it. I'm 6'1" and I would definitely do that again.

We flew from ORD to FCO last month, and I had purchased Premium Economy for us. Not exactly sure how it worked out this way, but when I went to select our seats, I was able to select Business Class seats/pods without any additional upgrade. I've flown a few times to & from Europe in regular economy and can say the splurge for this trip was well worth it and was absolute luxury to us. Our return flight (from London) on British Airways was Premium Economy, but it was just the "regular" seats with a bit more room -- still better than regular economy, though. If you're the type of person who's able to fall asleep on takeoff and not wake up until landing, or if you don't need a lot of room to stretch out, save your money and go economy. Otherwise, if you have the budget, give some serious consideration to an upgrade.

On American, I usually pay a smidge more to get the first row of economy seating. I take sleepy medicine when I fly, so it’s not really worth it for me to pay too much more - plus I’d rather spend the money on experiences and more vacations!
I quite regularly fly transatlantic, and the regular seats are fine. Save the money to do something fun when you get there!
We did Main Cabin Extra which is a little more leg room but only $120 more. Didn't want to spend anymore than that on the flight.
Premium and coach are the same seats just with more leg room first class are larger or wider seats
We are in Rome currently and just flew that same flight from row 26. Was not too bad but could have used the extra leg room

We survived it. It was tough, but I got up and stretched a lot. I even changed into stretchy pants after takeoff so I could curl up a little easier, then changed back before landing so I didn't look like I was in pj's lol
It was really uncomfortable for me and I’m only 5’1”. I didn’t get any sleep. Ours was 11 hours though. If you can afford it, would pay.
All depends where you are in life. When I was young, I flew economy, and now that I am older and can afford it I never fly less than business class.
Put your flight into seatguru.com so you can see what seat specs you’ll have on the plane you’ll be on. Maybe that will help you decide.
We are flying delta air in late September. I just called yesterday. There are no upgraded seats available for us. The planes are going to be packed.
It’s worth the upgrade. Absolutely.
If u can afford it YES

Yes! We did the premium economy last year to Italy. The flight back got cancelled so we got stuck in main and the comparison was palpable.

We could sleep overnight so we could stay awake when we got to Bologna.

If you can swing it, I say go for it.

They are the same MC seats as domestic with the same legroom etc…

They are fine. Are they super comfortable? No. Adequate.

I have always flown economy seats, (3 trips to Europe last year) this year I booked PE seats. They were only $400 more RT, not double the ticket price! I searched times and connections etc and got the cheapest PE seats. Business was 3x the ticket price.😱

But PE seats are a game changer for me! Soooo much more legroom, nice wide seats, plenty of arm rest room on center seat etc… felt very pampered ( for an economy girl!😂)

Sooo if you’ve got the money… go for it!
Fly premium economy if you can.

If you don’t have an assigned seat, you may be able to get on the app you used and select a more desirable seat for approx 40.00. I did it a a trip to Rome and Barcelona recently. Good luck and have a wonderful trip.
We splurged on business class for our flight to Rome in September. Actually looking forward to it. Delayed 30th anniversary and we’re worth it!
You can prepare yourself for long haul flights to make it as comfortable as possible- even with economy seating. I’ve been watch several utube videos on this very topic. Very helpful information!
Try flying from Australia economy.. 9 hours is only the first stop over !!
We did main cabin to and from Barcelona . It was annoying when the people in front of us put their seats back . My legs did swell on the way back
was for me for 13hrs ...rather spend my money on better stuff ..
Yes it is the dream liner is not that great for a long flight like that

Not worth it to pay more. Ten of thousands of people sit in those seats everyday for 9 hours or longer and are just fine. You'll be talking about Rome for years to come. Seats on the plane will barely be an afterthought.
I divide the price difference for the upgrade by the amount of hours in the flight and see if I want to “make that much an hour” to sit an a less comfortable seat. ￼
Mary Ann Mills try to get at least an exit row
Yes, they are comfortable enough. It is not worth paying double for more comfortable seats.
Pay double!!!!!
Depends on the seat and the aircraft.

Depends on your height and size. If you’re over 6ft not a lot of leg room. If person reclines in front of you takes up a lot of that leg space- are you ok with that? If so good to go. If need to stretch legs often etc then should upgrade to plus or whichever has more leg room. Helps a ton.
nope
I’m a flight attendant . That route is serviced by a 787. I’d say they are okay for 9 hours. If you can get row 24 or row 12 in MC that’s ideal. For me, I’d pay extra for Premium Economy.

They were pretty bad but we survived and spend the money on experiences for our trip instead.
To put it into perspective, it’s less seat and leg room than a southwest flight

If it’s an overnight flight, we always go for premium or business. That way we can try to get some rest. We stick to MC for the way home because it’s usually a day flight. That’s a good way to save you a little money.

I’ve travelled a lot to Europe and China. I will say business class is much more comfortable than main cabin seating. You just have to decide if the big fare increase is worth it. My wife and I are flying direct from DTW to Rome in Sept and seated in main cabin. 9 hrs is tolerable vs 16 hr flight time to China; that would be rough in MC!
First class is nice when you get a free upgrade but we get there at the same time I’d rather just get the cheapest tickets and spend more money once I get there
We did economy, it was ok.
I fly yearly to Italy EWR-NAP and always in MC bc I’m cheap 😆
Same flights - and doing premium seats. Especially going there. We feel it’s definitely worth the extra money - getting more comfortable seats and only two in the row.
In my opinion well worth the upgrade to premium economy.
Pay for premium and book the very first row, you will have more leg room. We were very happy with it.
They’re comfortable enough if it’s all you can afford‼️

I just flew Ireland and back 7 hours and was in main cabin and totally fine , cause alls you do is watch movies and sleep on an overnight flight anyway ! Save money for food , hotels and excursions! Plan on booking Italy next year and will stick to the main cabin as well , flights are expensive enough right now , but gosh looking at people in first class I was jealous! ( my husband 5’11 and had no c/0)

We won’t do anything less than premium economy. We flew economy once back from England - and never, ever again. If you have long legs - it’s not even a bougie thing - it’s just that your knees will literally be IN the seat in front of you. It’s ridiculous.

We fly premium economy to Italy in a month, and business back. Sometimes the extra money is just worth it. The difference in the way they treat people between premium economy or higher, and economy, is also outrageous. I’ve never in my life felt as much like a third class citizen as I did sitting in economy. Never, ever again.

I say it’s absolutely worth upgrading.
My son in law is 6’7” so he wouldn’t fit in economy. We all opted for Premium Economy and we’re glad we did. It was worth the extra cost to us.

comments.comment_text: Vespa!

text: I have been researching The Tour Guy to see all the sites in one day. We are staying at The Westin. One review said they were not returned to their hotel and had to take a taxi. Does anyone have info about this? Also when they say “Skip the Line”, is it really saving us time?

comments.comment_text: We used The Tour Guy for a skip the line tour of the Vatican. They were great, we were in before many of the other tour groups and got to the Sistine Chapel at opening so it was not as crowded. Tour guide was terrific. We also did a Capri boat trip which was also excellent. There was pick up and drop off at hotel. I saw that some tours only had hotel pickup, you need to really read the description of what is included. The Tour Guy is also great if you call with a question.
We did skip the line and it was worth it. Those lines are really long and we went right by them.

text:
It would be very interesting to just manage with carry on only as I always take too much and I experienced the large suitcases over the cobblestones! I can't find the comment that I wanted to answer in regards to Carry on luggage limits.
I live in Australia and our National carrier Qantas hand luggage limit is 7Kg Economy, 10Kg Premium Economy. It is the same for Etihad and Emirates that I have also travelled with.
What is the secret?

comments.comment_text:
Buy ultralight carry on luggage. Laundry services (wash/dry/
fold) are everywhere so you really only need a week’s worth of clothes. We are retired and travel for months at a time with just carry on. So much easier and you can buy anything you need :-)
Secret is you wear the sane things every day or buy there. However they are checking roll bags on many flights these days.
Ultralight case. Soft sided canvas is probably the best and you can easily do carry on. Family of 4 and we had 7.5 a person.
I am from Aus too. I usually take a small suitcase (with 4 wheels ) and check it in, plus a carry on smaller bag. Usually works well. 😊
You can Google Erica’s and Emirates.

We’re midway through 3 weeks with only a small carry on each. And I realize I brought things I really didn’t need. Doing laundry is the key. We’ve had W/D at a couple Air B&Bs and a laundry service at another. We have no trouble on the trains and watch those with lots of luggage struggle.

We spent 6 weeks in Italy and Switzerland with carry on only. Underwear and shirts easily washed out in a sink.

Remember no one cares what you’re wearing. I wear a lot of black! 😃
You need to check the measurements on individual websites.

This is what we took for 6 weeks 12 countries we are from Nz flew qantas and Emirates and lots of other airlines. Our bags were from Kathmandu 35 litres go from backpack to suitcase . No problems at all with any airline train or boat re carry on highly recommend
US hand luggage has different bag dimensions and not the 7kg carry on limits that we have in Australia.
Just check on their websites
we just travelled with Emirates Aust to Italy, it was 7kg carry on 30kg checkin
We took checkin backpacks, and I packed far to much, and it was heavy to carry around

The secret Is 99% of people who travel carry on are not like us from Oz or nz .. seems like most American airlines don't have weight limits just size limits .. im checking in a med sized bag and my carry on fits inside it.. so its not heavy.. im going for 2 months si 7kg is 2 outfits...my case is 55ltr and has backpack straps and wheels only 1.9kg empty .. so far it's at 12kg packed ..

We are travelling from Australia for 5 weeks and doing carry on only. It is very easily done. Check the website for each carrier. We are flying Singapore into London, Ryanair to Italy and Malta and home with Emirates.
I go a lot to Italy from Australia, I use Qatar, I wear a crossbody + backpack & carry on small case that isn’t a problem for me🌻
I didnt take carry on ( from Aus) but we did take small bags to check in ( 50 litre rip curl) and a foldie each.it was easy!
Also i fitted heaps in those bags!!

Each airline is different. I would refer to your airline website. We travel 4-6 weeks at a time. We each, pack a carry on with one under the seat bag. We find doing laundry once a week is easier than pulling a huge suitcases. Have a great trip!

text:
Anyone visited Ravenna?
We currently have 3/4 of a day plus our overnight stay booked as a sort of “down day” from all the rest of the trip.
It’s all the usual suspects of the general region.
Rome, La Spezia, Cinque Terre, Florence and Venice.

It looks small, quaint, easily explored and relaxing. The Byzantine mosaics look intriguing and the beach-ish area.
However I’ve not seen it mentioned much at all.

I’m interested to hear if anyone else has visited it and enjoyed it.

Thanks!

comments.comment_text: There are multiple churches with fabulous Byzantine mosaics! Definitely worth a visit.
We spent a day there while staying in Bologna. Its lovely. The mosaic work is beautiful. I recommend it!
We took an antique train there and spend several hours. Definitely worth a visit.

It’s a great choice. A little out of the mega tourism circuit, but still know all over the world. Totally deserved a visit especially if you are into Roman history.

About food, don’t forget to try the piadina. It’s a must do.
The mosaics are gorgeous!!! Get tickets early - small walkable area but mosaics are in several sites. Dante’s tomb is there as well…
We stayed in lido de Pomposa last year and had a fantastic family holiday. Must see: Comacchio, san marino and bologna, ferrari museum in modena!
Ravenna is a pearl! Go! Don't miss San Vitale!
One of my favorite places in the world.

Loaded with UNESCO sites within walking distance, Ravenna is a very walkable gem. Make sure that you get reservations for Mausoleo di Galla Placidia because only certain number of very small group can enter there for exact 5 minutes. Walk to the official ticket office in town and buy a combo tix regardless of visiting all sites on the ticket. This is the only way to enter the famous Mausoleo. Weekend can be very difficult, so reserve early! If you have a car, you can drive to Rimini and Republic of San Marino in one day
Have wanted to go for awhile while in Venice thanks for info
Flat comfy shoes...so much beauty to see!
Loved the mosaics. Recommend a conducted tour . Then you can go back to enjoy them at leisure.
Italy Is full of hidden treasures, I just wonder why most people visit always the same 3 or 4 places...

Ravenna is a nice city. But it is a city so I myself wouldn’t call it quaint. Parts of it can be bustling. It wasn’t a “down day” for us, it was a destination. We wanted to see the incredible mosaics and we spent a few days enjoying ourselves as we
did.

So I think it’s an excellent stop. And the fact that it isn’t mentioned much is all the better. Italy is full of amazing places that are too often overlooked because 90 percent of tourists flock to the same 10 percent of places. Branching out from the “usual suspects” is a great thing to do. You can often explore without being elbow to elbow with thousands of other people as you discover some wonderful places overlooked in the age of mass tourism.

Wishing you a fun time in Ravenna.
It is very small & manageable in a day! I loved the mosaics - they are breathtakingly beautiful!

Loved it! The mosaics are truly amazing. Visited as a side trip between Venice and Florence in 2018 (?). My travel buddy wanted to go, I knew nothing about Ravenna. Those mosaics have “stayed with me” .

Ravenna is amazing! We took a tour with Tours by Locals and we did a tour that took us to see 3 sites for mosaics and were told all about them. Then we went to a master mosaic artist and we made our own mosaics. It was super fun! Kids had a great time.

Bologna was great! We spent 10 nights there and we had a blast eating our way around the town. We also did a private gelato making class and it was so much fun. Now, we are gelato snobs and cannot eat just any gelato. 😆
Ravenna is wonderful. Crazy mods, wonderful Basilica of San Vitale. It eats very well
Loved Ravenna! The mosaic tiles tour is great! Really amazing!

Go to @Ristorante Ai 45 Ravenna and get the Tiramisu! SO good!
Also Ristorante Ai Battibecchi was excellent!
LOVE Ravenna! Mosaics & piadine ftw! Go to Ca’ de Vèn, which is like if there was a wine tavern at Hogwarts.
Love it

Definitely worth a visit…in addition to the extraordinary mosaics, you can visit the tomb of Dante. Near the tomb, a magnificent cloister where we happened upon an outdoor recital. Gorgeous. Easily walkable distances, and although we weren’t in Ravenna to shop or dine, we would have been spoiled for choice. So yes, great choice!
The basilica of San Vitale is a favourite of mine

Please please please get off the beaten path. You will not regret it! Just because a town or a province is not talked about on the social media, it doesn't mean it's not worth visiting. So, yes, go to Ravenna! And go to Parma, Pisa, Treviso, Trieste, Lago (Lake) Trasimeno, Viterbo and surrounding areas.

We stayed one day in Ravenna in June prior to cruising. It has a lovely, small historic centre, the mosaics are gorgeous and well worth a visit. 24 hours was probably enough though. We spent two days at the beach after the cruise, the beach is fantastic but a word of warning, take insect repellent, we were eaten alive by mosquitoes. We stayed at a very nice hotel in Punta Marina, Terme Beach resort.
Omg Loved Ravenna!!!! If you go make sure to see the marvelous churches with Byzantine mosaics!!!

Ravenna is amazing! A little more bohemian vibe but lots to see! The mosaics, Dante’s tomb, the Basilica of San Vitale, the Mercato are all wonderful! Less tourists as well! Great food and friendly people. I highly recommend it!
The mosaics will amaze you!

The Byzantine mosaics of Ravenna are breathtaking! We did a day tour from Bologna, booked a tour of 3 UNESCO sites through Getyourguide site. Glad we did it. We really enjoyed the tour. The Ravenna itself is a very pretty walkable city.
We had a very lovely day there, lots of cute stores and restaurants.
My cousin has a beach bar there. It’s lovely!

We spent the day there on the way to Bologna and it was lovely. Basilica of San Vitale is a must. If you visit during high season, I recommend purchase ticket in advance to avoid waiting in line in the heat.
It looks amazing

Ravenna is beautiful, but overlooked like so many other beautiful places in Italy.If it s your first time in Italy it's obvious you want to see the usual Rome/Florence/
Venice...but there are HUNDREDS of enchanting towns/ lakes/
mountains/
beaches in Italy!
We Italians spend most of our week end discovering new places! Try Umbria (Assisi, Orvieto, Spoleto, Spello) or Sardinia with its turquoise Caribbean like beaches, or Lake Garda or Lake Maggiore and their islands full of gardens! What about Piedmont and the hilly Langhe Region, secondo to beauty just of Tuscany? And my hometown, Turin, 2000 years old, first capital of Italy: majestic, elegant, royal palaces, excellent cuisine!

text:
Hello, I looked at-TrenItalia site to book tickets for a Sunday in September from Rome to Venice. It takes me to the next date. They can’t all be sold out and I also checked another Sunday in August just to be sure. Does the Trenitalia high speed train not run on Sundays?
Italo site has the tickets available for a Sunday. It seems to have trainsआणखी of 4 hr. Duration as well. Does it matter which train I take? Is premium class on Italo comfortable?
Rail.ninja seems to be easier to navigate. And it lists the Italo trains.

Italo is cheaper than Trenitalia and has the same, if not better standards. Both are high speed trains. Premium Class is confortable and there are served some snacks. I usually buy economy (confortable aswell) and upgrade it to premium when Italo makes some special offer (no big difference between economy and premium). Italian here ✌️
We have always used ItaliaRail to book.
I like Omio to compare different modes of transportation and EASY to use!

Adjust the date/time. It will show.
Consider purchasing higher level of service you can afford since you will be stuck on a train with strangers for 4 hours.
It could be from the time zone you’re booking from. You’re computer/phone has a date and when it translate to the site it’s whatever the equivalent day/time. This happened to me (California).
It does run in Sundays . We just booked Rome to Venice fir September. Hope u manage to get tickets. 😊
I find trainline.com easy to use
Buy Italo. I even prefer it compared to Frecciarossa.
I had the same issue yesterday. Just sent the time to way before you actually want it. For example, to see the 8am trains I set it to close to 1 am and then it pulled my results
